name: Kepler-125
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-125 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-125 is a star with 0.40999999999999975 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.51 times its radius. It is located 601.24 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-125 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-125 b

Kepler-125 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 4.16 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-125.

The mass of Kepler-125 b is 7.59 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-125 b is 2.37 that of Earth. At 7.59 Earth masses, Kepler-125 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-125 c

Kepler-125 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.05 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 5.77 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-125.

The mass of Kepler-125 c is 0.47 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-125 c is 0.74 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-125 c is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-125, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
